messages: 7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:02): hello
7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:02): are mysql subqueries optimized differently than if they are executed separately?
9ca10a97571747c802904ac96509eaf4 (02:08): corp: quite commonly, yes
7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:09): HarrisonF: ah - why is that?
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:11): corp: because you do not want to read needless data
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:11): if you can break out early you do
4aacc4645af8fb0ca83df966d52110ad (02:11): how to install mysql-workbench on ubuntu (debian based)?
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:11): and you dont want to do needless comparisons
7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:11): ah, i see whats happening
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:12): or load too much data at once
7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:12): the IN subquery optimization
7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:13): so in general is it better to use actual values in an IN statement than to use  subquery?
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:13): err .. how do you get those values?
7d1ed578bd144ea78e6bc89537aec68b (02:14): perform the inner query, then perform a query substituting the results of that inner query in the IN)
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:14): anyways if you have a short list of values you can hardcode it will be faster yes
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:14): but if you mean doing the query in separate steps
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:14): and then inserting the data from the inner query into the outer
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:14): then no .. it should not be faster
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:15): if it is .. then something is seriously screwed up
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:15): which makes the optimizer do all the wrong things
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:15): in which case you may want to re-analyze your table
bd2594496377911bc0dea822872a80da (02:15): how can i select non distinct fields?
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:15): section31: self join
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:16): err

9ce30ddf0128522375f75b49afaffeee (02:40): pound showandtell ?

ac5c74b64b4b8352ef2f181affb5ac2a (02:40): gib: (EXPLAIN Syntax (Get Information About a SELECT)) : http://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql/en/EXPLAIN.html
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:40): explore if you can make a compound index
6857d579004c31f1efc078cb6c8c543f (02:40): gib: all fields that appear in where clauses or joins on should be indexed.
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:40): but usually only one index will be used per table
6857d579004c31f1efc078cb6c8c543f (02:41): and yes, compound indexes are even better
8942b6d335d4f7f98fc102a85908d86c (02:41): haha nice guys :)
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (02:41): recent mysql versions might use multiple indexes under some circumstances
6857d579004c31f1efc078cb6c8c543f (02:41): lsmith: only true if you do joins by primary key only.
8942b6d335d4f7f98fc102a85908d86c (02:41): ok i'll try explain to see first then
